Ken,

   It appears that you keep attempting to recast the substrate inputs=
 
and outputs such that the hypercube input topology remains constant. 
Not=
 taking anything away from HyperNEAT's ability to exploit 1d/2d/3d 
geometr=
y in which the hypercube input topology remains constant, the 
more general=
 question of when the hypercube input topology is not 
constant, what do yo=
u do? Please address this specific issue. The 
answer to this question will=
 help to identify the 
applicability/limitations of HyperNEAT.

Thanks,
   =
Andy Carl


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> w=
rote:
>
> Thomas, this is a great question that highlights an important are=
a 
for 
> further research.  We can speculate on the right approach in this=
 
case 
> (and I have my hunches) but we won't know until we do some 
exper=
iments 
> and try ideas out.
> 
> To give some of my thoughts, perhaps the =
most obvious thing is 
similar 
> to what you suggest:  Have two separate i=
nput sets, one for 
the "type A 
> info" and one for "type B info."  
> 
> =
The way this would look is e.g. if A was 2D and B was 2D then the 
CPPN 
> =
would have 4 inputs, 2 represent A source nodes and 2 representing 
B 
> so=
ource nodes.
> 
> Then, I would still have only one set of outputs.  I am s=
till a 
little 
> unclear on why you say the outputs are from the second su=
bstrate?  
In 
> my understanding, this is still all one substrate, it's ju=
st that 
it 
> collects inputs from two different sources.  But it can stil=
l exist 
> with only one set of outputs.  So if the outputs are 2D, the CPP=
N 
would 
> have 2 more inputs representing the output area for a total of =
6 
inputs 
> (and one output representing the weight of a connection in the=
 
> substrate).
> 
> If there was a hidden layer you could have it exist in=
 either the 
same 
> geometry as A, the same geometry as B, or the same geo=
metry as the 
> outputs.  (For example by introducing a z dimension to any =
of 
these)  
> Or you could have each kind of hidden layer all at once.
> 
=
> Of course, as you note, there are a lot of ways to do something 
like 
> =
this.  I think it will be a great issue to explore, but it may 
require 
> =
starting with a very simple domain that isolates the issue (i.e. 
> orthogo=
nal input types) so we can concentrate on that rather than 
on a 
> specifi=
c domain with its own complications.
> 
> One other issue to note is that e=
ven if two sets of inputs are in 
> effect unrelated, it may not necessaril=
y hurt antyhing to put them 
in 
> the same geometry.  For example, they co=
uld be two separate planes 
in 
> the same cube.  On the face of it, it see=
ms like that could cause 
> problems, but we don't yet know whether the sit=
uation is that 
difficult 
> to deal with in practice.  There could also be=
 hidden relationships 
> that are not obvious but still exploitable in a su=
rprising way.
> 
> ken
> 
> 
>
